author: By Nadya Tolokonnikova
title: Putin Didn’t Hate Navalny. He Envied Him.
description: My friend Aleksei’s dream of a beautiful Russia is immortal.
content: It’s 2007, a warm, sunny spring day in Moscow. It’s my first rally, and I’m nervous. I’m 16, silly and shy, falling in love with courageous and loud people around me. I hear my quiet voice join others screaming, “Russia without Putin.” We lock our arms and together push the police out of the street. Russia could be free: It’s a new feeling for me. This is where I see Aleksei Navalny for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 20, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 20, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about European leaders’ growing concerns surrounding the threats posed by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia misstated the day on which the widow of Aleksei A. Navalny spoke at the Munich Security Conference. It was Friday, not Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Heads to California to Add to His $42 Million Haul in January
description: President Biden’s ability to raise cash has been a bright spot as his polling numbers remain stubbornly low.
content: President Biden arrived in California on Tuesday for a series of high-dollar campaign fund-raisers in some of the wealthiest and most heavily Democratic parts of the country as he seeks to add to the $42 million he raised for his re-election campaign in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: At Harvard, Some Wonder What It Will Take to Stop the Spiral
description: At a summit of university presidents, the talk was about Harvard and its plummeting reputation.
content: When 70 university presidents gathered for a summit at the end of January, the topic on everyone’s mind was the crisis at Harvard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Williams
title: Kicking Native People Off Their Land Is a Horrible Way to Save the Planet
description: Forcing Indigenous people out of protected areas they help manage and rely on is not the way to achieve biodiversity and climate goals.
content: Over 600,000 tourists travel to Tanzania’s Ngorongoro Conservation Area each year, and many will catch a glimpse of the Great Migration: the famed trek of more than one million wildebeests and thousands of zebras, gazelles and other animals crossing over the Mara River into Kenya and back. Yet the Tanzanian government believes it can attract many more tourists seeking the safari adventure of a lifetime: five million by 2025, bringing $6 billion with them per year, according to a recent plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Wife, Protector and Now Political Heir: Yulia Navalnaya Rallies Russians
description: The wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader long shunned the spotlight, but his death in prison may make that impossible. “I have no right to give up,” she said.
content: It was August 2020, and Yulia Navalnaya, the wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader, was striding through the battered, gloomy hallways of a provincial Russian hospital, looking for the room where her husband lay in a coma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Ukraine’s Latest Loss May Be Worse Than Expected
description: Also, the Supreme Court declined to hear a case on race and admissions. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The fall of the eastern Ukrainian city of Avdiivka to Russia over the weekend was a major symbolic loss for Ukraine and the West. But while American officials initially argued that it was not a significant strategic setback, that calculus could soon change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Eisen, Joshua Kolb and Barbara McQuade
title: There Is Much More at Stake in Trump’s Manhattan Case Than Just Hush Money
description: Alvin Bragg is hoping to reinforce a principle about business and our democracy.
content: With Justice Juan Merchan’s proclamation last week that jury selection in the Manhattan prosecution of Donald Trump will begin on March 25, it is time for a reappraisal of the case. The charges brought by Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, have been overshadowed by the three other criminal prosecutions of Mr. Trump, but the 34 felony counts constitute a strong case of election interference and fraud in the place where Mr. Trump lived and conducted business for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Does Beer Before Liquor Actually Make You Sicker?
description: We asked alcohol researchers to explain what will — and won’t — prevent a hangover.
content: Q: I’ve heard this phrase for years: “Beer before liquor, never been sicker.” But is it true?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Walmart Reports Rising Holiday Sales as Shoppers Seek Value
description: The number of transactions at the retail giant rose 4.3 percent, but the average ticket price decreased by 0.3 percent, a sign that shoppers spent a little less during shopping trips.
content: Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer, said on Tuesday that sales rose in the fourth quarter over the previous year, offering one of the first looks at how Americans shopped during the crucial holiday season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: More Wall Street Firms Are Flip-Flopping on Their Climate Pledges
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 20, 2024.
content: “This was always cosmetic. If signing a piece of paper was getting these companies into trouble, it’s no surprise they’re getting the hell out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Arrests U.S. Citizen, Accusing Her of Treason by Aiding Ukraine
description: The country’s main security agency said the 33-year-old detainee lived in Los Angeles. A lawyers group said she was accused of donating $50 to the war effort.
content: Russia’s main security agency said on Tuesday that it had arrested a dual citizen of Russia and the United States on accusations of committing state treason by raising funds for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Three Questions About Rafah
description: A looming battle in the southern Gaza city embodies the brutal dynamics of the conflict.
content: The looming battle for Rafah — a city on the southern end of Gaza, farthest from where Israel’s invasion began — embodies the brutal dynamics of the conflict. The war is both a military operation against Hamas, an extremist organization that has vowed more terrorist attacks against Israel, and a humanitarian crisis that has brought death, hunger and displacement to Gazan civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Scientists Find Genetic Signature of Down Syndrome in Ancient Bones
description: The discovery may help shed light on how prehistoric societies treated children with rare conditions.
content: Scientists have diagnosed Down syndrome from DNA in the ancient bones of seven infants, one as old as 5,500 years. Their method, published in the journal Nature Communications, may help researchers learn more about how prehistoric societies treated people with Down syndrome and other rare conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: South Africa Says Palestinians Are Enduring ‘Extreme Form of Apartheid’
description: The hearings, which focus on Israel’s occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, make up one of the two matters regarding Israel currently before the International Court of Justice.
content: At a hearing before the U.N.’s highest court, South Africa on Tuesday called Israel’s policies toward Palestinians an “extreme form of apartheid” and argued that its occupation of territory sought for an eventual Palestinian state was “fundamentally illegal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: How Bob Moore, of Bob’s Red Mill, Got Grocery-Store Famous
description: The natural foods entrepreneur hit upon a distinctively American style that matched the homey packaging of his products.
content: Bob’s Red Mill Natural Foods was founded in 1978, but it wasn’t until several years later that the company hit upon the thing that made its oats, groats and other natural food products so immediately recognizable on supermarket shelves. That was when the likeness of Bob Moore, the company’s eponymous founder, began appearing on the packaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jon Stewart Takes Notes From Tucker Carlson’s Coverage of Russia
description: “I have much to learn,” Stewart said. “‘Disguise your deception and capitulation to power as noble and moral and based in freedom.’ Yes, master.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Hundreds of Ukrainian Soldiers Are Missing
description: Also, Julian Assange’s appeal and a U.S. cease-fire proposal in Gaza.
content: Hundreds of Ukrainian troops may have been captured by Russia, or disappeared, during Ukraine’s chaotic retreat from the eastern city of Avdiivka. The loss could deal a blow to Ukraine’s already weakening morale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Corey Kilgannon
title: N.Y.P.D. Drones Carrying Rafts Could Join Lifeguards in Beach Rescues
description: Mayor Eric Adams, an avowed technophile, said the drones would be used to assist lifeguards at Coney Island as part of a pilot program starting this summer.
content: This summer, struggling swimmers off Coney Island might be met not just by a young lifeguard in an orange suit but also by assistance from above, in the form of a buglike device delivering an inflatable float.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ramin Ganeshram
title: Bringing to Light the Cuisine of Hercules Posey, George Washington’s Enslaved Chef
description: For more than 200 years, the story of the nation’s first presidential chef has been lost to history, but a group of historians is working to give Hercules Posey his due.
content: On Feb. 22, 1797, while George Washington celebrated his 65th birthday at a ball in Philadelphia, his celebrated chef, Hercules Posey, slipped from the meager enslaved quarters at Mount Vernon, the president’s Virginia estate. Stepping into the damp night under the light of a waning moon, he found his freedom, only to be lost to history for the next 200 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fintan O'Toole
title: A Love Song to His Roots
description: In “Remembering Peasants,” the historian Patrick Joyce presents a stirring elegy for a vanishing culture.
content: In 1970, when John Lennon wanted to denounce the bourgeoisie in his angry song “Working Class Hero,” he delivered the ultimate insult: “You’re still [expletive] peasants as far as I can see.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Fritzsche
title: Ukraine, Gaza and the Long Shadow of German Guilt
description: In “Out of the Darkness,” Frank Trentmann details the way people in the country that started World War II are still confronting and atoning for the atrocities of their government.
content: “Stalingrad” is what Germans talked about as they settled down for coffee and cake on Sunday afternoons in the first five decades after World War II — the “bitter fate” of prisoners in Soviet camps, the five million German soldiers who lost their lives in the wider conflict, and the widows and orphans they left behind. They brought up “Dresden” and the 20 million people who had lost their homes in the Allied bombing. Almost every family told stories of one of the 12 million refugees who fled the Red Army’s advance or had been expelled from the eastern territories, from Breslau, Danzig and Königsberg. One after another, they followed paths of self-pity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Senator Tammy Baldwin Draws Republican Challenger in Wisconsin
description: Eric Hovde, a wealthy businessman, is the most prominent Republican to enter the race after two members of Congress declined to run.
content: Eric Hovde, a Wisconsin businessman, on Tuesday announced his campaign for the Senate seat held by Tammy Baldwin, a Democrat, giving Republicans a prominent candidate in the state after two sitting members of Congress declined to run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Bed-Stuy Loft Transformed With an Out-of-the-Ordinary Renovation
description: They didn’t expect their new Brooklyn home to flood a week after they moved in. But ‘with the destruction, there was an opportunity.’
content: After years of renting, Jackson Owens and Flora Jin bought a loft in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and it felt like the stuff of dreams. A week or so later, it was more like a nightmare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: A Dead Baby Was Found at an Airport in 2005. Her Mother Was Just Arrested.
description: The authorities said that genetic evidence was used to find Annie Anderson of Washington State. She will be charged with first-degree murder in the death of her child, who came to be known as Baby Skylar.
content: The dead baby girl was found in a trash bin in a women’s bathroom at main airport in Phoenix on Oct. 10, 2005. Wrapped in newspapers and a towel, the newborn had been stuffed into a plastic bag from a Marriott Hotel, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The Quiet Way Democrats Hope to Expand Their Power at the State Level
description: The Democratic Governors Association is beginning a multimillion-dollar effort aimed at appointing more state judges.
content: Locked out of power on the Supreme Court and still playing catch-up against Republicans in the federal judiciary, Democrats are hoping to gain a political advantage on a less visible but still important playing field: the state courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Trump’s G.O.P. Is a Confederacy of Fakers
description: Lindsey Graham, J.D. Vance, Mike Johnson and other Republicans are waving the white flag of surrender on Ukraine, all at Trump’s behest.
content: I’ve got a suggestion for the next Trump-G.O.P. fund-raising scheme. You know how sports memorabilia stores sometimes sell basketballs autographed by an entire N.B.A. team? Well, I was imagining that Donald Trump could sell white flags at $1,000 a pop that say, “We surrendered Ukraine to Russia,” autographed by him and the House and Senate MAGA sycophants he’s assembled to deny Ukrainians the weapons they need to stave off Vladimir Putin’s onslaught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: ‘Jelly’s Last Jam’ Returns, Bringing a Jazz Tale to a New Generation
description: Jason Michael Webb, the show’s guest music director, said he wants audiences at the musical about Jelly Roll Morton to experience “a time period that does not exist anymore.”
content: The team behind the Encores! revival of “Jelly’s Last Jam” is not looking to reinvent George C. Wolfe’s ambitious 1992 Broadway show. But they do hope that this rendition, opening on Wednesday at New York City Center, will introduce the musical to a new generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Cade Metz
title: Inside the Funding Frenzy at Anthropic, One of A.I.’s Hottest Start-Ups
description: The company raised $7.3 billion over the last year, as the lure of artificial intelligence changes Silicon Valley deal-making.
content: Last May, Anthropic, one of the world’s hottest artificial intelligence start-ups, raised $450 million from investors including Google and Salesforce. It was the beginning of an astonishing funding spree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: The Shocking Death That Has Devastated Gamers for Decades
description: One of the most consequential scenes in video game history is being remade by the creators of Final Fantasy VII. Will they kill Aerith again?
content: There were early warnings in the 1997 role-playing game Final Fantasy VII that Cloud Strife harbored delusions of grandeur. An identity borrowed from an old war buddy. Genetics spliced from a parasitic alien. A toxic relationship with a super soldier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Want a Better Society? Try Better Buildings.
description: An obsession with luxury is transforming cities into bland, isolating landscapes. Architecture should be for creating community.
content: When my family moved to Washington so that I could cover the Trump administration, I wanted to live in an apartment building. My wife objected, ascribing the desire to my Soviet childhood spent in a communal flat. I conceded the point: If the desire was rooted in a Proustian yearning, all the more reason to honor it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Student Arrested in University of Colorado Shooting That Killed Two
description: Nicholas Jordan, 25, who was enrolled at the school, was arrested on murder charges in Colorado Springs.
content: A Michigan man was arrested on Monday on murder charges related to the fatal shooting of two people, one of them his roommate, in a dormitory at the University of Colorado campus in Colorado Springs, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Wine Shop Millesima USA Doubles in Size for Its World-Class Selection
description: A cookbook for overlooked vegetables, mushroom candles for your dinner table and more food news.
content: Upon entering the new Millesima USA wine shop, relocated earlier this month from a few blocks uptown, you’re in a no-frills array of shelves, racks and bins in a well-lit windowed setting. Emphasizing Bordeaux, Burgundy and Italy, with other major regions, including Spain, the United States and Australia, represented as well, there are pedigreed bottles into the low three figures. But that’s before you step into the soaring circular central core of the store, like a Guggenheim rotunda of wine they’re calling the forum. Even if you’re not in the market for premier cru Burgundies, well-aged first-growth Bordeaux, tête de cuvée Champagnes and sought-after Italian wines priced into the thousands and stacked to the ceiling, it’s worth visiting this section to view it, like an oenophile tourist, as you might a collection of fine art. And they’re all for sale. Originally opened in 2006 by a family-owned company founded in Bordeaux in 1983, and which does most of its business online, it was successful as a neighborhood wine shop. Now, more than double the size, with a world-class inventory, and offering futures (an opportunity to reserve rare wines in advance), the Upper East Side store steps into the gaping carriage trade void left after the venerable Sherry-Lehmann Wine & Spirits sadly plummeted, then failed. As for the spirits side of the alcohol business, they only carry a token selection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: When Eyes in the Sky Start Looking Right at You
description: New satellites that orbit the Earth at very low altitudes may result in a world where nothing is really off limits.
content: For decades, privacy experts have been wary of snooping from space. They feared satellites powerful enough to zoom in on individuals, capturing close-ups that might differentiate adults from children or suited sunbathers from those in a state of nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Furry Trims and Nosy Neighbors: How London Fashion Week Turned 40
description: Burberry, JW Anderson, Erdem and Simone Rocha flew the flag for British design talent this season as LFW celebrated a milestone.
content: It was the Sunday of London Fashion Week and the last model had just stepped off the runway at the JW Anderson show. A heaving scrum soon descended on the designer, a sea of phones held aloft like antennas. Jonathan Anderson’s collection had been a nostalgic British jumble of chunky knits and trench coats, school uniform staples, retro thermal underwear sets and hats like Grandma’s gray pin-curl wigs, all chucked into a subversive tumble dryer for a warped take on what once felt familiar. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Lefty Driesell, Hall of Fame College Basketball Coach, Dies at 92
description: He built Maryland into a national powerhouse and became the first coach to win more than 100 games at each of four major college programs.
content: Lefty Driesell, the Hall of Fame coach who built nationally prominent basketball teams at the University of Maryland in the 1970s, and who at his retirement in 2003 was the nation’s fourth-winningest N.C.A.A. Division I men’s coach, died on Saturday at his home in Virginia Beach. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee and Vivian Nereim
title: Israel May Put New Restrictions on Visiting Aqsa Mosque as Ramadan Nears
description: Reducing access to Al Aqsa, the sacred mosque compound in Jerusalem that has long been a flashpoint for tensions, may set off unrest, some Israelis warned.
content: The Israeli government was locked in debate on Monday on whether to increase restrictions on Muslims’ access to an important mosque compound in Jerusalem during the holy month of Ramadan, leading to predictions of unrest if the limits are enforced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Morales
title: How Beyoncé Jolted the Cuban Singer Daymé Arocena Into a Fresh Era
description: The prodigious jazz singer came to embrace her inner pop star on a new album made with Visitante from Calle 13.
content: Running her fingers through her dreadlocks in an outdoor cafe overlooking San Juan’s grittily trendy Calle Loiza strip, Daymé Arocena reflected wistfully on an old flame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: U.S. Prepares ‘Major Sanctions’ Against Russia Over Navalny’s Death
description: President Biden has said there is “no doubt” that Vladimir V. Putin’s government was behind the death of the Russian opposition leader.
content: The Biden administration is preparing “major sanctions” against Moscow in response to the death of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, a White House official said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachelle Bonja, Lynsea Garrison, Stella Tan, Paige Cowett, Liz O. Baylen, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Corey Schreppel and Alyssa Moxley
title: Stranded in Rafah as an Israeli Invasion Looms
description: Two Gazans on life in the territory’s southernmost city.
content: This episode contains strong language and descriptions of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: Hundreds of Ukrainian Troops Feared Captured or Missing in Chaotic Retreat
description: The fall of Avdiivka to Russia may be more significant than it initially seemed as Ukraine struggles with morale and recruitment.
content: Hundreds of Ukrainian troops may have been captured by advancing Russian units or disappeared during Ukraine’s chaotic retreat from the eastern city of Avdiivka, according to senior Western officials and soldiers fighting for Ukraine, a devastating loss that could deal a blow to already weakening morale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: He Wanted to Play Basketball. He Finally Got the Chance.
description: Arthur Dukes, CUNY’s player of the year, went through hard times before he broke out at LaGuardia Community College.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll find out about the improbable story of how someone went from playing pickup basketball to being a star at LaGuardia Community College in Queens. We’ll also look at former Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s effort to torpedo a state ethics commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: A Clever, Joyless Look at the ‘Commonplace Horror’ of Marriage
description: Lyz Lenz opens up about an unhappy union, and what she learned from it, in “This American Ex-Wife.”
content: When friends asked why I married a man 30 years older who didn’t have any money, I had three answers: 1) I loved him. 2) I’m an idiot. 3) I knew I couldn’t be married forever and this way, nature would take care of that problem for me (which it did).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: The Quiet Diplomat Who Shaped Biden’s Global Economic Policy
description: Mike Pyle, who will leave the administration this month, helped broker agreement with Europe and other allies over clean energy, China and Russian sanctions.
content: In the fall of 2022, two top Biden administration officials met in New York with a key European diplomat. Over dinner outdoors, they strategized about how best to throttle Russia’s oil revenues in retaliation for its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: That ‘Unimaginable’ Smell in Cape Town? A Docked Ship With 19,000 Cows.
description: As the stench wafted more than a mile inland, the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals found a buildup of dung in the animals’ cramped holding pens.
content: When a smell so foul that locals called it “unimaginable” wafted over Cape Town this week, a search for the source of the stench choking the scenic South African tourist destination led to the city’s harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: telltale
description: This word has appeared in 73 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word telltale has appeared in 73 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 19 in “Test Yourself: Which Faces Were Made by A.I.?” by Stuart A. Thompson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: Seeking Purpose Among the Dead in ‘Spiritus/Virgil’s Dance’
description: Dael Orlandersmith’s slender new solo play is a meditation on living that seems also like a curveball response to loss.
content: To Virgil, the audience’s guide through Dael Orlandersmith’s slender, searching new solo play, “Spiritus/Virgil’s Dance,” there is something hellish in the sight of the miserable masses commuting to dreaded jobs that bring them nothing more than the ability to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Constellation’ Review: Alice in Wonderspace
description: A sci-fi mystery from Apple TV+ turns quantum physics into a dark fairy tale.
content: In “Constellation” on Apple TV+, the Swedish actress Noomi Rapace stars as Jo Ericsson, an astronaut whose time on the International Space Station takes a tragic and mysterious turn. The superbly capable Jo battles overwhelming odds to get back to Earth and to decipher why she feels so out of place once she’s there. But the real hero of the story — its emotional center and vigilant conscience — is Jo’s young daughter, a solemn girl with a significant name: Alice. To understand what’s up with her mom, she’ll have to go through the looking glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear New Case on Race and School Admissions
description: The decision, along with an order this month declining to block West Point’s admissions program, suggests that most justices are not eager to immediately explore the limits of its ruling from June.
content: The Supreme Court cleared the way on Tuesday for the use of admissions criteria intended to diversify the student body at an elite public high school in Virginia, declining to revisit the role race may play in admissions months after it sharply curtailed affirmative action programs in higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Olsen
title: Shape-Shifting Lingerie for All Body Shapes
description: The artist Michaela Stark’s new line highlights body parts women have been conditioned to hide.
content: It has been a while since a little belly pooch had fashion appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Important Is It to You to Keep Mementos From Your Life?
description: Photos, handwritten notes, stubs from movies and concerts — are these keepsakes to cherish or clutter that’s destined for the trash?
content: Do you know anyone who saves things that are meant to commemorate events and serve as reminders of special moments? Are you such a person?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Nikki Haley will address the state of the race today.
description: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor who polls indicate is badly trailing Donald J. Trump with her home state’s primary just days away, will hold a campaign event today addressing the state of the race.
content: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor who polls indicate is badly trailing Donald J. Trump with her home state’s primary just days away, will hold a campaign event today addressing the state of the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Larissa Anderson, Wendy Dorr, Charles Finch and Carole Sabouraud
title: The Many Selves of Leslie Jamison
description: Her new memoir “Splinters” ties them all together with stunning prose.
content: Charles Finch, a contributor to The New York Times Book Review, can’t stop thinking about Leslie Jamison’s new memoir, “Splinters: Another Kind of Love Story.” There are a lot of books about motherhood. There are a lot of books about divorce. This is a book of unusually clear intelligence and compassion, he says. “Splinters” was published on February 20, 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A U.S. Cease-Fire Proposal, and Navalny’s Widow’s Pledge
description: Plus, satellites could soon be looking right at you.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: At Lolita, Serving Mexican in Midtown, Agave and Sugar Cane Drinks Rule
description: Frog Club opens in the former Chumley’s space, the Crave Fishbar team opens a sushi spot and more restaurant news.
content: The name couldn’t be more innocent or less Nabokovian. Lola, the 2½ -year-old daughter of Jillian Lockhart, an owner, was the inspiration. This unusual two-story lounge and restaurant has a distinctive point of view when it comes to drinks. The bar, shelves and lockers throughout the place have restricted the spirits offerings mostly to those that are made from agave, like tequila and mezcal from Mexico, and sugar cane, mainly rums produced globally. Cachaça, another sugar cane spirit, is included. Marshall Minaya, a partner and the beverage director, and the head bartender, Carlos Kennedy-Lopez, worked to develop drinks to showcase the various spirits. The food is Mexican, by the chef Carmelo Calixto, and offers many of the usual suspects: guacamole, empanadas, tacos, enchiladas and carne asada. The bar area at the entrance is framed by glowing arches, a design statement that we also saw recently at Coqodaq. The ground-floor level is more of a lounge than the upstairs, where there are tables and another bar. Throughout, the space is enriched by a deeply vibrant palette. This place occupies the building that also houses the group’s Madame George, a subterranean lounge, and Valerie, a bar and restaurant. Each has a separate entrance at the same address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Alito Renews Criticism of Landmark Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage
description: In a statement, the justice raised concerns that those with “traditional religious views” would be “‘labeled as bigots and treated as such’ by the government.”
content: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. on Tuesday renewed his criticisms of the Supreme Court’s landmark decision recognizing the right to same-sex marriage, saying that people who oppose homosexuality risk being unfairly “labeled as bigots and treated as such.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Constant Méheut
title: Russian Pilot Who Defected to Ukraine Is Believed Dead in Spain
description: The apparent death in Spain of Maksim Kuzminov is likely to fuel speculation that it was the work of Russia’s intelligence services.
content: Maksim Kuzminov pulled off a daring escape last summer when he defected to Ukraine and handed his military helicopter over to Ukrainian commandos in exchange for half a million dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korean Doctors Walk Out, Protesting Plan to Increase Their Ranks
description: Physicians say the government’s plan to admit more students to medical school ignores the real cause of doctor shortages: harsh conditions and low wages.
content: Hundreds of interns and residents at major South Korean hospitals walked off the job on Tuesday, disrupting an essential service to protest the government’s plan to address a shortage of doctors by admitting more students to medical school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Women Outnumber Men in South Korea’s Sports Stadiums
description: Experts say it has to do with stadium safety and the influence of K-pop fan culture.
content: Each time the South Korean men’s soccer team scored against Singapore during a recent 5-0 rout in a World Cup qualifier, the roar from the home crowd came largely from women, who held nearly two-thirds of the tickets to the match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Volkswagen Leans on Electric Vehicles and Nostalgia to Grow in U.S.
description: It and other foreign automakers are trying to exploit upheaval caused by new technology to gain market share from their dominant rivals.
content: Probably only Americans of a certain age remember when the Volkswagen Beetle was the best-selling imported car in the United States and the hippest ride to a Grateful Dead concert was a Volkswagen Microbus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Flight of Fancy
description: Robert S. Gard senses a novel opportunity.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Monica Hickey, Doyenne of Bridal Gowns, Dies at 100
description: As the director of salons at Henri Bendel, Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue, she spent decades outfitting brides-to-be for their grand ceremonies.
content: Monica Hickey, who for decades swathed celebrities and socialites for their lavish nuptials in the haute bridal salons at the New York department stores Henri Bendel, Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue, died on Jan. 26 in Valle de Elqui, Chile. She was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: Quick, Cozy Soups That Taste Like They Simmered All Day
description: Clever cooking tricks add tons of body and flavor to Ali Slagle’s chicken and rice soup and Ham El-Waylly’s vegetable tortilla soup.
content: Hi, Five Weeknight Dishers. It’s Krysten, former editor of this very newsletter, stepping in for Emily this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emilia Petrarca
title: The Unlikely Return of the Doily
description: In fashion as well as products for the home, lace — once seen as the fustiest of fabrics — is suddenly looking fresh.
content: When you think about lace, “modern” probably isn’t the first word that comes to mind. The centuries-old fabric, made by looping, twisting or knitting thread into various open-weave patterns, is more likely to evoke images of quaint cottage curtains or your grandmother’s bridal veil. But now, more and more young designers are incorporating the ethereal textile into their work, motivated by both personal nostalgia and a longing for the tactile and handmade in our increasingly virtual age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: A Nerve Center for the Right Wing Rises in Washington
description: The Conservative Partnership Institute has become a breeding ground for the next generation of Trump loyalists and an incubator for policies he might pursue. Its fast growth is raising questions.
content: In the lobby of the grand Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables, Fla., where a sprawling new force in Washington’s right-wing ecosystem, the Conservative Partnership Institute, was holding its winter conference, the former Trump legal adviser Cleta Mitchell was exultant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Broadway’s Crunchtime Is Also Its Best Life
description: Eighteen openings in two months will drive everyone crazy. But maybe there should be even more.
content: Broadway is the pinnacle of the commercial theater, a billion-dollar cultural enterprise and a jewel of New York City. So why is it run like a Christmas tree farm?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: For Carla Hall, It’s Been a Bumpy Climb to a ‘Top Chef’ Life
description: The bubbly host of a new TV food-and-travel series plays up the comedy, but her ascent has required navigating setbacks like the demise of “The Chew.”
content: Carla Hall’s tarot card reading was running long. Astrology, numerology, psychics, the Chinese zodiac — she’s open to all manner of metaphysical messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Wall Street Is Already Placing Bets on the Biden-Trump Rematch
description: Traders and strategists are thinking about all the ways that November’s election could alter the mood in markets.
content: Nine months ahead of the presidential election, investors are already thinking about how financial markets might respond to the outcome of the vote, and how they should trade to prepare for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Blending Into the Background at a Barbershop
description: Barbershops may be some of the last places where supporters of Donald J. Trump or President Biden can debate in real, messy life. A political reporter visited one in Las Vegas to understand the discourse.
content: I spend a lot of time in strip malls. It’s not glamorous work, and they may not be the most obvious places for a New York Times political reporter to hang out. But I’ve visited many over the past few years to try to understand political attitudes across the country, to speak with voters after they shop for groceries or pump gas. And for all their monotony, strip malls often have some unexpected gems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel Orders New Evacuations in Northern Gaza as U.N. Suspends Food Deliveries
description: Residents of two neighborhoods in Gaza City were ordered to evacuate, and the World Food Program described scenes of chaos in the north too dangerous to allow it to provide food supplies.
content: Israel’s military ordered two neighborhoods of Gaza City to evacuate on Tuesday amid signs of hunger and mounting desperation in the northern part of the enclave at a time when the focus of Israel’s offensive has shifted south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vik Jolly
title: Living on the Edge in California
description: In Dana Point, three cliffside mansions teeter on the edge of beauty and peril after storms seemed to weaken the ground beneath them.
content: Few places are as enjoyable as the headlands in Dana Point, where ocean waves lap rhythmically at the coastline and, on a clear day, the outline of Santa Catalina Island emerges from the Pacific Ocean, the silhouette of a bold sentry in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jason Karaian
title: Will Food Prices Stop Rising Quickly? Many Companies Say Yes.
description: Food companies are talking about smaller price increases this year, good news for grocery shoppers, restaurant diners and the White House.
content: Few prices are as visible to Americans as the ones they encounter at the grocery store or drive-through window, which is why two years of rapid food inflation have been a major drag for U.S. households and the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Listen to tracks by Maggie Rogers, Angélica Garcia, Jessica Pratt and more.
content: Though we’re still less than two months into 2024, it already feels like it’s going to be a busy year in the music world. In March and April alone, a bunch of A-list artists have new albums slated for release: Taylor Swift, Beyoncé, Ariana Grande, Kacey Musgraves, Justin Timberlake and Shakira, to name just a few.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Unpacking the Washington Math for a Big Payment Deal
description: Regulators have been tough on big financial mergers, though there are nuances in Capital One’s $35.3 billion takeover bid for Discover.
content: Capital One’s $35.3 billion takeover to buy Discover Financial Services will create a colossus in the fast-growing credit card industry and a more powerful force in the payment networks that underpin the consumer economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley
title: 4 Ways Autocrats Have Used Interpol to Harass Faraway Enemies
description: As an election looms, strongmen are finding new ways to use the international policing organization to pursue dissidents.
content: Interpol is the world’s largest police organization. It serves as a powerful bulletin board that governments and law enforcement agencies use to team up to pursue fugitives across the globe. At its best, it helps track down killers and terrorists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irina Aleksander
title: How Tom Sandoval Became the Most Hated Man in America
description: He turned last year’s season of ‘Vanderpump Rules’ into the best in reality TV’s history — and ruined his life in the process.
content: Valley Village is a Los Angeles neighborhood just across the freeway from Studio City, near the southern edge of the area locally referred to with both affection and derision as the Valley. There, at the end of a quiet, leafy street of ranch-style homes stands what real estate agents have come to describe as a “modern farmhouse,” which its current occupant, the reality-TV star Tom Sandoval, has outfitted with landscaping lights that rotate in a spectrum of colors, mimicking the dance floor of a nightclub. The home is both his private residence and an occasional TV set for the Bravo reality show “Vanderpump Rules.” After a series of events that came to be known as “Scandoval,” paparazzi had been camped outside, but by the new year it was just one or two guys, and now they have mostly gone, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatol Magdziarz, Maria Varenikova and Emma Bubola
title: Protesting Polish Farmers Block Much of Ukraine’s Western Border
description: The farmers are demonstrating against what they see as an influx of Ukrainian food products crowding the Polish market and undercutting their livelihood.
content: As the war continued to rage in Ukraine’s east, much of its Western border was blocked on Tuesday by another fight, this one with Polish farmers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Kevin Draper
title: 2 Men Charged With Murder in Kansas City Super Bowl Rally Shooting
description: Prosecutors said two teenagers also face charges. More arrests are possible, they said.
content: It began, prosecutors said, with one man accusing another of staring at him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: Israeli Military Releases Videos It Says Shows Bibas Family Members in Captivity on Oct. 7
description: “When we saw the video, it really tore our hearts out,” the sister of one of the hostages said. Hamas has said three members of the family died in an Israeli airstrike; Israel has not confirmed the report.
content: Relatives of an Israeli mother and child who appeared to be shown in captivity in Gaza in newly released videos from the day of the Hamas-led attack said Tuesday they hoped the footage would call attention to the urgency of freeing the hostages.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘His Wife Invited Me Over’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: At the Hanoi orphanage, 4-month-old Leo would not meet my eye. Good! Leo’s withdrawal suggested he was attached to his current caregivers. If, after being separated from his birth mother, he attached once, he would likely attach again. Our first night, Leo cried inconsolably as I held him. His 12-pound body had already absorbed so much disruption. After hours of pacing, I opened our balcony door. The sun was rising onto our first full day as a family. I looked down at Leo’s face and saw the beginning of a smile. “We’re going to be OK,” I promised. — Anna Monardo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Powerball Posted the Wrong Numbers. Now He’s Suing for $340 Million.
description: Powerball organizers in Washington, D.C., said they “mistakenly posted” winning numbers in January 2023. The holder of those numbers is suing for negligence and emotional distress.
content: The string of numbers on the lottery ticket that John Cheeks bought matched those posted on a Powerball website. Had he beat unfathomable odds to win the $340 million grand prize?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley Says She Is Not Dropping Out: ‘I Feel No Need to Kiss the Ring’
description: She pledged to continue her pursuit of the Republican nomination past Saturday’s primary in South Carolina and said she had “no fear of Trump’s retribution.”
content: Nikki Haley isn’t going anywhere. She has said as much behind closed doors at fund-raisers, reiterated it in recent news media appearances and made the promise on the stump, in front of audiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Catherine Porter
title: Can the Olympics Rejuvenate One of France’s Poorest Corners?
description: Officials hope an Olympic Village can transform a Paris suburb known for poverty and crime. But big plans have failed before.
content: Parisians are already grumbling about the crowds for this summer’s Olympics. They envision sweaty tourists jamming the subway cars, making the hell of commuting even more, well, hellish. They are planning their summer escapes; at worst a “télétravail” schedule to work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Ice Cream
description: What’s your go-to flavor?
content: Do you love ice cream? Do you prefer classic flavors or more fresh and novel ones?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Buruma
title: The 17th-Century Heretic We Could Really Use Now
description: The philosopher Baruch Spinoza’s commitment to free thought and reason is sorely needed in our time of demagogues and dogma.
content: The Enlightenment philosopher Baruch Spinoza almost died for his ideals one day in 1672.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Setback for the Transition to Electric Vehicles
description: Responses to plans to ease the deadline on car emissions. Also: Donald Trump and abortion limits; keeping Aleksei Navalny’s work alive; $399 Trump sneakers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley
title: Strongmen Find New Ways to Abuse Interpol, Despite Years of Fixes
description: The international police organization has toughened oversight of its protocols, which autocrats have used to pursue dissidents. But the autocrats have adapted.
content: For years, strongmen and autocrats had a novel weapon in their hunt for political enemies. They used Interpol, the world’s largest police organization, to reach across borders and grab them — even in democracies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Bensimon and Todd Heisler
title: Their Asylum Case Seems Strong. But Instead of Hope, They Feel Despair.
description: Fleeing political persecution, a family hoped the United States would take them in. After the city evicted them, they questioned whether they should have come.
content: On the last day of 2023, Thierno Sadou Barry walked from his homeless shelter near Times Square to Harlem, looking to buy inexpensive suitcases he could fill up with all his possessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: What’s behind Wall Street’s flip-flop on climate?
description: Political and legal risks are mounting for banks and asset managers.
content: Many of the world’s biggest financial firms spent the past several years burnishing their environmental images by pledging to use their financial muscle to fight climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Aleksei Navalny’s widow keeps fighting.
content: Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny, vowed to continue his fight against President Vladimir Putin’s autocratic rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Rubin
title: Damo Suzuki, Singer Who Ignited the Experimental Band Can, Dies at 74
description: His free-spirited music ignored genre boundaries. “If you’re a creative person,” he once said, “it’s important to break rules.”
content: Damo Suzuki, a Japanese vocalist best known for his role with the revered and influential German experimental rock group Can during its most crucial period, died on Feb. 9 at his home in Cologne, Germany. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: Could You Pass the Presidential Physical Fitness Test Today?
description: Whether you loved it or loathed it as a kid, the exercises can still be a revealing measure of health — now that no one’s forcing you to do them.
content: If you went to an American public school between 1966 and 2012, you probably have memories of sweating through the Presidential Physical Fitness Test — a gym class gauntlet that involved a mile run, sit-ups, pull-ups (or push-ups), a sit-and-reach and a shuttle run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: A Writer With Skin in the Game
description: The essayist Leslie Jamison has become known for her careful balancing acts of self-exposure.
content: “If the self is a guesthouse, most of the rooms are full of ghosts,” Leslie Jamison said on a recent Monday afternoon in a Columbia University lecture hall. Ms. Jamison, wearing an ethereal blue maxi dress, stood before a projector screen showing 19th-century spirit photography. “Being haunted can be a state of abundance,” she said. “Living in the ghost hotel is a state of abundance. Memories are raw material.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Olivia Wang
title: Spicy Food and Dental Implants: Low Prices Lure Hong Kongers to China
description: Hong Kong residents are finding in Shenzhen, the mainland city next door, lower prices, better service and tasty cuisine.
content: Shuen Chun-wa, 81, and her husband hurried toward a green bus with two dozen other Hong Kong residents, dragging empty suitcases. They had purple tour stickers on their jackets and were headed to shop in Shenzhen, a bustling Chinese city that sits on the northern side of the border with Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Jaap van Zweden Bids Farewell, and Other Classical Highlights
description: The Philharmonic’s maestro ends his tenure, Igor Levit comes to Carnegie Hall, and the Metropolitan Opera takes a chance on reviving two recent hits.
content: The New York Philharmonic’s spring gala is not usually of much musical interest. It tends toward mild fare — just enough to keep the donors happy before dinner and dancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Former YouTube Parenting Host to Serve Up to 30 Years in Prison for Child Abuse
description: Ruby Franke documented her strict parenting strategies, which included punishing her children by refusing to feed them, on social media. She was arrested last year.
content: Ruby Franke, the host of a now-defunct parenting channel on YouTube who in December pleaded guilty to four counts of aggravated child abuse, was sentenced to 1 to 15 years in prison for each of those counts, to be served consecutively, a judge ruled on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Beginning of the End’ as Assange Case Returns to Court
description: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, has been in prison for nearly 5 years, fighting a U.S. extradition order. A hearing is his last chance to be granted an appeal in Britain.
content: Since 2019, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has been held in a high security prison in southeast London while his lawyers fight a U.S. extradition order. Now, that particular battle may be nearing its end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Emily Flitter
title: What to Know About Capital One’s Proposed Acquisition of Discover
description: Before two of the largest credit card companies in the United States can complete a $35 billion deal, they’ll face an uphill battle with regulators.
content: Capital One announced on Monday that it would acquire Discover Financial Services, in a deal to combine two of the largest credit card companies in the United States. But before the transaction can be consummated, the deal must overcome regulatory scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Prince William Calls for End to Gaza Fighting ‘as Soon as Possible’
description: In a measured public statement, the heir to the British throne said that “too many have been killed” in the war between Israel and Hamas.
content: Prince William, the heir to the British throne, called on Tuesday for an end to the fighting in Gaza as soon as possible in a rare, if measured, public statement on the bloody conflict between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Riding His Baseball Fame, Steve Garvey Disrupts the California Senate Race
description: A fierce contest between Democratic members of Congress has become a strategic battle that could send the 75-year-old Republican to the general election. He still has little chance of winning office, however.
content: In the crowded race to succeed the late Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, Steve Garvey stands out both for his celebrity and for how little he has actually campaigned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Paul
title: Culinary Hubs Put a Twist on Home Cooking
description: Developers are transforming clusters of old homes into micro restaurants to cater to the needs of surrounding neighborhoods.
content: Nestled in the dense, residential Los Angeles neighborhood of Victor Heights, a tightly packed plot of Craftsman and Victorian homes has stood the test of time, serving as single-family residences in one of the city’s oldest neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Believing Is Seeing
description: Of Moscow, New York and partisan perception.
content: What was most startling about Tucker Carlson’s recent trip to Russia wasn’t his obsequious interview with Vladimir Putin but his gushing days afterward over how wonderful a place Moscow is. But then again, he was a special guest of the country that invented Potemkin villages (even if the original story is dubious), and making sure he saw only good stuff must have been easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Ma
title: To Become a Lion
description: Both a ceremonial custom and a dynamic sport, lion dancing is a cultural practice that spans generations and continents.
content: I was born in Sydney, Australia, as the only child of parents who immigrated from China with little financial security or knowledge of English. I spent most of my childhood in Sydney’s Chinatown, by my mother’s side during school holidays as she worked the checkout at a Chinese supermarket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdullah H. Hammoud
title: I’m the Mayor of Dearborn, Mich., and My City Feels Betrayed
description: I worry Biden will be remembered not as the president who saved American democracy but as the president who sacrificed it for Netanyahu.
content: “Dearborn doesn’t sleep,” I recently told an out-of-state visitor to my hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: For Zelda Williams, Daughter of Robin, a Goth Zombie Comedy Is Cathartic
description: As the director of “Lisa Frankenstein,” she embraced a tale in which no one was concerned whether grief was palatable to others.
content: Zelda Williams never intended a teenage zombie rom-com to be her feature filmmaking debut. For one thing, the project, “Lisa Frankenstein,” was a big concept to sell, a high-camp period piece set in the fuchsia-and-teal ’80s. There was grief, violence and a floofy-haired love interest who was — not to put too fine a point on it — not only mute but dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Yulia Navalnaya’s Account Is Briefly Suspended by X
description: An account created by Aleksei A. Navalny’s widow on Monday disappeared and then returned hours later. The social media company said the suspension had been a mistake.
content: The social media platform X temporarily suspended on Tuesday an account created by Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of Aleksei A. Navalny, and then restored it, saying it had been mistakenly flagged by its automated security protocols.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Andy Newman
title: Child Abuse Investigators Traumatize Families, Lawsuit Charges
description: Lawyers for a group of New York City parents argue that the Administration for Children’s Services uses “coercive tactics” that traumatize the families it is charged with protecting.
content: A sweeping class-action lawsuit filed against New York City on Tuesday argues that the agency that investigates child abuse and neglect routinely engages in unconstitutional practices that traumatize the families it is charged with protecting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: In Alaska, the Rare Thrill of ‘Wild’ Ice Skating
description: When a two-week, high-pressure window of cold, clear weather froze lakes south of Anchorage, adventurous skaters, including our writer, were ready.
content: I’d been waiting for months when I finally got the call from Alaska last March: Wild ice was on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa and Maansi Srivastava
title: Selling Weed, but Making It Fashion
description: A day with Brett Heyman, the designer who is trying to push the legal cannabis market in a more stylish, sunny direction.
content: Two weeks ago, an accessories designer named Brett Heyman sold weed, legally, for the first time in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Beefs Are All the Rage in Comedy. As Mike Epps Knows, They’re Nothing New.
description: His new special nods at his past resentment of Kevin Hart and others. It’s part of a stand-up tradition of feuds like the ones fueled by Katt Williams.
content: Mike Epps may be the only stand-up comic alive who’s upset that Katt Williams didn’t insult him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Four Missing Fishermen Off Florida Gulf Coast
description: The men, who were described as experienced fishermen, set out for a boating trip on Saturday from Venice, Fla., and did not return home, the authorities said.
content: The United States Coast Guard has called off a search for four missing boaters who set out Saturday morning for a day of fishing off Florida’s Gulf Coast and never returned home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Cassandra Vinograd and Thomas Fuller
title: U.S. Vetoes Security Council Cease-Fire Resolution
description: The United States said the resolution could have disrupted its negotiations to free hostages and secure a temporary cease-fire, but its vote drew outcry from many diplomats and aid workers.
content: The United States on Tuesday cast the sole vote against a United Nations Security Council resolution that would have called for an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, saying it feared it could disrupt hostage negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Beatles Get a Biopic. A Fab Four of Them, Actually.
description: The Oscar-winning filmmaker Sam Mendes was given full rights to the band’s music and their life stories for the unusual quartet of films, planned for 2027.
content: The British director Sam Mendes has signed on to direct not one but four biopics about the Beatles, each telling the story of the Fab Four from a different member’s point of view.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Charging Documents Against Dominic Miller
description: Two Missouri residents, Dominic Miller and Lyndell Mays, were charged with murder in the shooting that erupted after the Super Bowl parade in Kansas City, Mo. Here are the charging documents against Dominic Miller.
content: Two Missouri residents, Dominic Miller and Lyndell Mays, were charged with murder in the shooting that erupted after the Super Bowl parade in Kansas City, Mo. Here are the charging documents against Dominic Miller.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Charging Documents Against Lyndell Mays
description: Two Missouri residents, Dominic Miller and Lyndell Mays, were charged with murder in the shooting that erupted after the Super Bowl parade in Kansas City, Mo. Here are the charging documents against Lyndell Mays.
content: Two Missouri residents, Dominic Miller and Lyndell Mays, were charged with murder in the shooting that erupted after the Super Bowl parade in Kansas City, Mo. Here are the charging documents against Lyndell Mays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pennsylvania State House 140th District Special Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania legislature special election.
content: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania legislature special election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Agency for Protecting Children Traumatizes Families, Lawsuit Says
description: A lawsuit says that investigators for the Administration for Children’s Services deceive and bully their way into people’s homes, where they rifle through families’ most private spaces, strip-search children and humiliate parents.
content: A lawsuit says that investigators for the Administration for Children’s Services deceive and bully their way into people’s homes, where they rifle through families’ most private spaces, strip-search children and humiliate parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find the 10 International Thrillers Hidden in This Text Puzzle?
description: See how many book titles you can identify in this literary word search puzzle.
content: See how many book titles you can identify in this literary word search puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘With Destruction, There Was an Opportunity’
description: They didn’t expect their new Brooklyn home to flood a week after they moved in. But they found a silver lining.
content: They didn’t expect their new Brooklyn home to flood a week after they moved in. But they found a silver lining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Ma
title: To Become a Lion
description: A martial arts master traces the evolution of lion dancing mapped through his path to teaching.
content: A martial arts master traces the evolution of lion dancing mapped through his path to teaching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa, Claire Hogan and Brent McDonald
title: How Nikki Haley Has Alienated Black Voters
description: Jazmine Ulloa, a political correspondent for The New York Times, explains how Nikki Haley, who is Indian American, has downplayed the influence of racism on American society and institutions.
content: Jazmine Ulloa, a political correspondent for The New York Times, explains how Nikki Haley, who is Indian American, has downplayed the influence of racism on American society and institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar, Neil Collier and Mark Boyer
title: Motaz Azaiza Captured Gaza’s Suffering. But ‘Nothing Changed.’
description: When war broke out in Gaza on Oct.7, Motaz Azaiza, a Palestinian photographer, turned his camera to covering pain and loss in a territory under siege. In doing so, he attracted millions of followers — documenting the war while also trying to survive it.
content: When war broke out in Gaza on Oct.7, Motaz Azaiza, a Palestinian photographer, turned his camera to covering pain and loss in a territory under siege. In doing so, he attracted millions of followers — documenting the war while also trying to survive it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Gazan Tailors Repurpose Covid Gear to Meet Diaper Demand
description: The lack of diapers has led some desperate parents to use plastic bags.
content: The lack of diapers has led some desperate parents to use plastic bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Julian Assange Supporters Rally Outside London’s High Court
description: Supporters of Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, protested outside the Royal Courts of Justice in London, where his legal team made a final bid for an appeal against a U.S. extradition order.
content: Supporters of Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, protested outside the Royal Courts of Justice in London, where his legal team made a final bid for an appeal against a U.S. extradition order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: California Endures Flooding After Another Atmospheric River
description: The latest storm uprooted trees and collapsed part of California State Route 84.
content: The latest storm uprooted trees and collapsed part of California State Route 84.
source.name: The New York Times
